Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery column-krater; interior: glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of warrior (advanced leg with added red greave remaining), moving to right, and lower part of draped figure to left (himation with red blob and foot remaining); the brown vertical line between the figures is either the warrior's spear or the other's staff; on far left, possibly part of a garment; below, brown dilute band and trace of black lower body.
Producer name: Attributed to: The Painter of Louvre F6
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd belongs to the same vase as Oxford AN1896-1908-G.556, AN1896-1908-G.557 (3 joining fragments), AN1896-1908-G.559, AN1896-1908-G.560, AN1896-1908-G.561 and G130.16. All sherds show warriors leaving home. The sherd may belong to the same vase as Oxford AN1896-1908-G.577.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 265, no. B191)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0146) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 94, pl. II, no. 12)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
